transcript.content: James Refuge Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: My name is James Refuge. I was convicted for armed robbery and murder. And, I was 18 years old when I committed the crime in 1969. And like, I went to court. I wasn't, I was on drugs, but I wasn't, the drugs didn't cause me to do what I did.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: What I did was because I was taught from a young age through my mother that was the only one that really had control over my life was my mother. But she always told me, never, always take care of my sisters and brothers. Never let nothing happen to them.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well I heard a conversation at the age of 16 my grandfather, my sister, one of my sisters asked my grandfather if he was going to buy them some, a new outfit for school, to get back to school. He told her no, so I heard this conversation at 16, and said well I ain't going to let that happen. I went to robbing and went to Payless and went to buy clothes for my sisters to go to school. Sisters and brothers.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Tell me a little bit about the people who raised you.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: All right, well my aunt raised me after I came out of the homes. I had an aunt named Doris Demay, she died.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so how old were you when you were put in foster care?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Fourteen.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, this is a year after your mother died?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: A year after my mother died. I was put in the Boys Home and I ran away from there and so they wound up catching up with me, living with my aunt and they sent me to the state industrial school for nine months. Where I stayed there. And then I got out at the age of 15.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And when I got out of that, I start staying with my aunt. Because my grandfather didn't want me under his custody no more. And I was 16 years old, roaming the streets and I went into the Fisher Project, a neighborhood where I used to hang out because I didn't want my sisters and brothers to see me in that part because we were living in Jefferson Parish.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And I didn't want them to see the life that I was living, I didn't want them to grow up the way I was living. And through the Fisher Projects, I watched it come from ground level. In reality, I thought, "I run the projects." You couldn't come in the project without coming through me. And that's how it was in that neighborhood.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you live there, did you spend the night there?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I just stayed there all day until dark. And then I had a bunch of friends, like a lot of girlfriends. All the girls used to call me Little James. That's what they called me at the time. And all the girls just wanted to be part of me. Just to say they went with me. Because the reputation that I had, I had a reputation, I was young put it like that. And through that reputation, I stayed there because I didn't have any relatives at all living in that Fisher Project.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I was living in Jefferson Parish with my grandfather at the time. Then my aunt moved and took me with her in Jefferson parish Street. And that's when, I just go hang in the projects. I wasn't, I quit going to school and hang out in the projects every day, every day. I wouldn't let my sisters or brothers come nowhere near around that project, and I didn't want them to know about it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. What about your father? Was he ever in your life?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, my father, sure, my father was living in Chicago. See, he used to come get me every summer and, to come stay in Chicago, but he tried to get me at the age of 16 to come live with him, but through my younger days in Chicago, I realized that I felt like I couldn't make it in Chicago the way, that life, the way I've seen the life in Chicago with the gang life. I don't like gangs, I never did.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And like, through my younger years, my daddy come every summer and bring me to Chicago with him. And, he'll bring me back and, I was real young then and that's when I got, my mother died, and I made 16, and I was stay with my grandfather, my daddy's daddy. And he tried to get me to go to Chicago. I said no because I couldn't survive up there. I felt like I wouldn't survive in Chicago.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, it's different culture.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You mentioned that you quit going to school. What was the highest grade of school?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Seventh grade. I went to Landry.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And so, how were you supporting yourself?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, I was doing little jobs. I thought working round, picking up paper, and stuff in the projects. I was in the little school, they called it. They would pay us, pay us $45 every Friday for picking up paper. We'd bring so many sacks to the office. Then I'd work at a grocery store in with a man that I used to go with his daughter.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: He had, this man had was Grant, he had some business and he'd let me operate his business for him when he not around. And that's how I was surviving and, like I said, I just started doing things I should've never did. Because when my mother let die, I didn't have control, nobody had control, she was the only one that really had control in my life.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, and you have 7 younger siblings?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you paint a picture, this is a long time ago and I'm just trying to picture, picture your neighborhood there. So, let's talk about the Fisher Projects, you spent most of your life up there?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I spent most of my life up there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: All right, so if I'm standing next to you, were both 18, both 17, looking around, what would we be seeing? What would I be seeing?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, you'd be seeing a lot of youngsters, you see a lot of people going in and out the projects. In and out buildings. You have, you know, certain neighborhoods where you have basketball courts, play football, and you see all kind of different types of activity going on. Drug dealers, whatever. And, we'd be doing a lot of things that, that the average ghetto people would do. And that's the way I was brought up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: In the late 60s?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: It was the 60s. The late 60s. The 1960s. The projects came up in 1965.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And through that, I stayed in that project until 1969.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I got it. Did you have a person that you were particularly close with? Like a best friend coming up?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about, about that person.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, this is a girl, a woman of mine. She had a son for me. Her name is Glennis Jones. Me and her were, we still close today. We had relationship at 1967. We've been having a relationship for 50 years. She's still with me today.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And we were so close. She had a son, my son wound up dying at the age of 26 because he wanted to be so much like me in the Fisher Projects. He had heard so much of me and like, through her. She asked me to marry her in 1978 while I was in this prison, I told her I wouldn't do it. Because I couldn't see the things that I see today. And like, she used to send my son up here to visit me with her sister, her sister had a husband up here to with me.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And, my son's daughter visit me at the age of 6 years old all the way till he made 16. When she was letting him, because she used to bring him too. Then, when she stopped coming, she start saying by him doing his time in Angola, we could visit regardless.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I used to work up in their building and everything in the 70s. My son made 16 years old, and he told me, he said, "Daddy, I can't come visit you no more." I said, "Why is that?" Because I told them about the life that you lived, and that you don't have no friends in that life. He was a drug dealer, so he said, "I can't come visit you because I got to carry a gun everywhere I go." I said, "You don't have to bring no gun in Angola." He said, "Well, I understand see, but I got to come all the way to the front gate with it in my car."

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: So, I said, "Well remember one thing, remember you don't have no friends in that life that you do, that you're living now. You can't trust no one." So, 1976, my son wind up getting shot up in the shoot-out, and he died. And from what I heard and what I was hearing about, he wanted to be, he heard so much of me that he wanted to be just like me. That was this woman that I'm still with today that was her son.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was her name? I missed that.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Glennis. Glennis Jones.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, who visits you up here?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Glennis Jones, my sister Linda Harrison, and, back in the day, they had all my sisters and brothers would visit me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: But they all got families now. And like, they had slowed down but right now, today, Glennis Jones and my sister and daughter participant right now, for visitation.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. If you had to pick an adult, of the adults in your life when you were growing up, who would you pick? Who took the greatest interest in you? Who would that be?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: My auntie Dun Demay.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Your auntie.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: But all my aunts and uncles, they all passed.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What's your last memory of your aunt?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Oh man, she was so close to me, she used to come visit me. You know, through the time I was arrested and, in this prison, and all, until she passed away.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember your last visit with her?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, it'd be way back in the 70s.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh really?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, did you find yourself getting into fights a lot at home?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, not at home.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Just on the streets. I was on the streets and outside the, in the neighborhoods. Like I say, I was so good with my hands I should have been a professional. I had the opportunity to do that. Guys would come talk to me about it at my younger age, you know. But I didn't know what I was facing until now. Until today, 17 years ago when the Lord touched my heart in this prison.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Even in this prison, I could've been a professional in here. But I was living so wild. The Lord touched my heart. He showed me how I let the devil use me, you know. To the point where, I don't live that life, I'm not the same person that first came here. I'm a totally different man now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, I do want to talk about that. Do you remember, we're just going to bring us back to when you got here? Do you remember the first time you got arrested?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Yes, sir. I remember I first got arrested in 1969, in December. And what the arrest, I was arrested in Chicago. And two guys that told on me, Larry Miller who was my fall partner, and the older guy Jim Johnson. They sent, they told the people where I was at. I was living in Chicago at the time. That's where I went, where I was when I went after I committed the crime.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And they come, they come got me. So, they brought me to Orleans parish. So, when I went to Orleans parish, I was young and like, I said, my first arrest.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That was your first arrest?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: My first arrest and I stood my ground because I felt like, if I do, because of my size, I wasn't going to let no one abuse me, no one handle me, no any kind of way. And I had to do what I had do, as far as fighting and other things.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is your fall partner serving a life sentence?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: No, I'm the only one. One Miller did, he wound up, the next, the same age as me. He had got 21 years, and the other guy, Jim Johnson, he got cut loose. The lawyer that was supposed to represent me, represented him. And that lawyer name was Harry Connick. And he refused to accept me as defender.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Fair. You briefly talked about drug use, were drugs and alcohol a big part of your life at the age of 18?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, I used it, but it didn't have no control over me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Would it be fair to say that you were mistreated as a child? Or do you not see it that way.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I don't see it that way. The only thing I did, I shouldn't have did what my grandfather, you know. I couldn't accept the things that he said and did. He had possession, he had full possession of me, or custody, put it like that. He had custody of me.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And the way I heard him talk to my sisters, I couldn't accept it. About he wasn't going to buy them anything. I feel like he supposed to do that. He supposed to buy us things. Because he was getting the forms for us. We wereliving in his house and everything.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you find yourself butting heads with him?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, we did. We had words. That's as far as we went.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. So, Mr. Refuge, one of the reasons that we wanted to speak with you and folks like you is that, you've served a very long time already, and you are widely considered to be rehabilitated.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: A model inmate. But let's go back for a second, and you tell me you spent a couple of years in the parish. And now your 21 when you come to Angola. Tell me about that. Coming to Angola in 1971?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: 1971, I was first brought to Angola. I was placed on death row for the electric chair. And I stayed on death row and, when they demolished the death penalty, well, I went through some physical contact with other prisoners because of my size, but I never lost.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And, next thing, I was boss, and you know, I would just say that I wouldn't let anyone handle me in no any kind of way. Do me no anything. Being on death row, they demolished the death penalty in 1972. And, to be honest, it was a blessing for me, because they demolished it two weeks before, my execution date was coming up.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And when I got back to court, it was like a sheet pulled from over my head. A comfortable mind where I see daylight and I felt the change in my life at that point because I'm looking. I was told that all my remittance, and everything was, that I didn't have no more chance in court. And you will be executed, by demolishing, it just took the sheet from over my head. I felt a whole lot different, so they brought me back to appellate court to get resentenced.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Then they brought me to Angola, and I had to go through, they put me in, in the cell block when I first came back to Angola in 1972 December. And, I had to go through a, the governor of public corrections, she had something to do with public corrections, Elayne Hunt. I had to go through her to get out the cell blocks to be placed in population in Angola.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And it placed me now, in 1973, they put me in the, on East side, it was called. And when I got in there, a lot of the guys had heard so much about me, that they said "Man, you James? You Little James?" And I said, "Yes, I'm Little James." He said, "Man, I thought you were six foot, 265 pounds." You got a lot of people afraid of you because of where I lived it.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And I regret the life that I was living then because I abused a lot of people. We took a lot of men pride. I did some things that were real hurtful to modern standards as of today. Because after I look back, because it was to the point where, I'd be honest with you and anybody else. In them years, them days, I was afraid to go home.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I was afraid to even come out of Angola because I thought I was going to lose my life the day I hit the streets because of the way I abused a lot of other men. In this place, because I thought my life would be like, more like in jeopardy. But as the years went by, I met some guys that's in a legal program and they showed me some points where, man they would look into your case. They knew I had some good grounds. But I said, well it doesn't matter you know.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And from that point, as I, through my living, I was 50 years old and where I lived then was Angola, in the prison. And the Lord touched my heart and turned my life around. And he went to showing me you know, in 1976 when I got stabbed, I couldn't believe it that I made it, I walked all the way to the hospital till I got the emergency room. That's when I passed out, they put me in an ambulance and they rushed me straight on the streets.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You were stabbed?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I was stabbed in the center of my back. Stabbed in the center of my back. And then, before that, I should have, I got stabbed right here, there's a mark there with butcher knife that came close to my throat and like I said, I got so many wounds in body because of my lifestyle. But today, it's totally different. I'm a totally different person than what I used to be.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Let's talk a little bit about that transformation? So, you're in a very violent prison and, in the 1970s, and you're just fighting.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Just fighting to survive.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Fighting to survive. And you get a couple of stabbings during that time. Last one in in 1976.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Right in 1976, the worst one.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, that was the one in your face?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: No, in my back.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: In your back, okay.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: The knife came this close to my heart.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh okay. And it was at that point that you thought you needed to change things, or did you just come right back fighting?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I just came right back fighting, still doing the same thing that I was doing. Up until 2000. That's when I changed my life around. 2000, the Lord touched my heart because, be honest with you, I could see God in reading the Bible and going to church, in the 70s. I thought they were using that as protection. That's what I looked at it.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Then, one day, I had a preacher man come, from off the street and was looking for me. Now, something told me, something said, "Man take it off, take this day off." I used to go, used to deal with recreation.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I was official, really, I was an instructor over officiating. And I used to deal with basketball at night, called basketball at Angola up here. So, God told me, he said, "Man, got a preacher be coming looking for you," so I said this one tonight, I'm going to take the day off and just see who it is.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: So, I'm Church, so I went to that Church that particular night and, it was in 2000. And got across with the men on the streets that I grew up with. And, he just so happened to call my name. I said, "Man I know that man, I know that guy." He was, was a preacher at that time. But this time, you know we did a lot of things on the street coming up in our teenage life.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: When I recognized who he was by making these names, calling these names, all these names and accusations I realized who he was then. And he turned to be preacher and it touched my heart, and from then on, he would share things with me about how he turned his life around. And, a week or so later, I got blessed and the Lord just touched my heart.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And I did start going to church and I did see what I had seen back in the 70s, about why dudes are going to church and why they are using the Bible. Why they're carrying, you know, the bible. Then I start reading the bible. God started showing me how he used me. And I got myself together and I thought like, I was working with God, this is my goal today. That was a big relief out this prison.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: My goal is to get out there, get my grandkids or young kids, and teach them not to make the mistake that I made. I want to work with these young kids, and show them because even this prison, they got some young guys come here that I sat down and talked to and I showed them what, and they got 2 or 3 years, or 5 years at the most and that is the deal. And I talked to them and they see me.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: They say, "Man, you're a blessed man, you don't look it." I don't look my age and I get around get as well as they do. And I showed them this ain't no place to be. 48 years in prison, incarcerated, I saw much. I destroyed my life, I destroyed 48 years of my life in prison. And I got grandkids. I got two daughters. And also had a son, my son, you know, died.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about your daughters.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Alright, my daughters, Shemain, one of my daughter's name is Shemain and she'll be 50 years old in December of this year. She is married, and she got one son. I never saw, I broke her heart because she was two years old last time I seen her. And their mother died at a young age from sickle cell anemia.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: My youngest daughter is 47. She'll be 48 in September. I never seen her. The close I came to seeing her was a picture of her, and the reason that came about, my mother-in-law told her so much hateful stuff about me, until she didn't want me communicating with her.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: So, what happened, one of my cousins were coming to visit me back in this time, and she asked my cousins if the person that she could visit do, do she think he knows her daddy. And well, they was going to college together. My cousin and my daughter, my youngest daughter, her name KayKay, and she said, "The person you go visit, he might know my daddy. Could you ask him do he know my daddy?" So, in the process of doing that, she said, "Well, what your daddy name?" And when she told her, "My daddy name is James Refuge." She said, she looked at her, "well, you already know. That's who I go visit. I'm visiting James Refuge, but didn't know you're related."

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: So, she wind up, so like my cousin, told her how you thought about telling her so she sent me pictures and write names on them because all the people grew up on me. Got all my nieces and nephews that I never met. So, she just so happened to send me a picture of my daughter without putting her name on it. She told me in the letter, said call me when you get this.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: I get on the phone, I get the picture and I look at it, and I said, "Lord have mercy." My daughter look exactly like me. So, I get on the phone and I said, I talk to her and she said, "You know who that is on the picture?" I said, "You don't got to say no more. That's my daughter." She said, "Yeah." I said, "She look just like me."

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: She got all my ways, she's exact. So, but my daughter, she went to school to be, she works for the crime lab. She do the blood tests on crime. She lives in Texas. Her husband is a private investigator. And, she got two kids. And like, my mother-in-law still don't want me and her communicating. But I'm going to get with her. If get out here today or tomorrow, that's going to be the first thing I do, catch up with my two daughters. I want to show them.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Have you tried to reach out to them from here?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, I don't know where their building be located, communicated. But I'm more sure that, from what they, see their grandmother hated me so bad, so much because I'm young. That's what bothered her.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: My mother-in-law wanted me to marry they momma. But I was too young to get married, and I didn't feel like, like me and her, their mother was young, and they didn't see the lifestyle as being married. But my mother-in-law got mad because I didn't want to accept the situation there. So, she split to spread the soil between me and my two daughters.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay sure, I understand. SoI have a question for you. So, you were almost, in 2000, you were close to 50.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Right, I was 50.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: This is a time when you said you changed your life around.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Why do you think it took you so long?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, the way I come up in this prison, the way I came up in life. And I didn't see the things that I see. Now even today, in those, prison ain't what it used to be any way no more. It's totally different. They say Angola is not what it used to be back in the day. There was a time that your shadow, if I laid out my bed and I just had my eyes closed, if I could be sleep, your shadow would wake me up.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: When I had to go to bed with a knife under my pillow or somewhere around me at all times. That's the way the life was back then. But nowadays, there's no violence concern. No violence taking place they say, or talk about it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. So, can you describe what your typical day now is? What is your routine today? What do you do?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well I work, I do painting, and I do construction work on the job. I'm the type of person that I like to work because the more I work, it motivates me. The more I get around much better. I'm all about some work. I don't care whatever, I'm going to help somebody to do some kind of work.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And, at my age, I'm 67 years old, and the more I work, the better I feel, you know. I don't try to work myself to death. But I do, I like doing something. I'm going do something regardless of my job and everywhere I go. That's what, you know, my motivation I have about life now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, so then after your job is over, where, how do you spend the rest of your day?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, there are two things I do to be honest with you, is that I watch the news, and from the news to my bed. I read my Bible. I read the Bible every day. I set it on the side of my bed, because the people I've live around are way much younger. I'm the oldest convict in my area where I live at, in my dormitory.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What dormitory?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Cypress 1. I'm the oldest convict in there. I been out longer than the average individual in that dorm. The ward, some will come and talk to me, and some don't. And some of them don't understand what I do. Because I'm trying to stay out of trouble, trying to stay away from trouble because, it's a time I may have some old-fashioned ways because the way I was brought into Angola, but it ain't that no more.

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: And the way I do things, I ain't going to disrespect no man and I don't want no man disrespecting me. And that's how they live, these youngsters nowadays, they're growing up, they learning because it takes certain situations, certain things for them to understand where they at, and what they're doing and what they got themselves into like me, myself. So, it took me some years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Now, knowing everything that you know, if you could go back to the James Refuge that arrived at Angola at 21, what advice would you give him?

transcript.speaker: James
transcript.content: Well, I'd give him, be conscious and be a person that has understanding. You know, try to share some positive things with a person. Because see like me, I see these guys see because I've felt like I should have been a professional ball player. I was so good at playing sports in this place. And I was teaching sports. And this is what I look at them, a lot of them like to sports and participate but always look back to where you should be that person on that TV screen.
